Apples are definitely more secure than Windows, and have a user interface most people agree is better than Windows (or Linux).

 You may want to keep your current PC, as Apple is currently porting Mac OS/X to Intel-hardware, and you could be able to put the Mac OS on your old hardware (unless it is RAM constrained as well, then it will be too slow to tolerate).

 With one exception, I have little personal information on the Windows based PCs we use for general Internet access on a wireless router. That exception is serial numbers and descriptions of personal assets for insurance purposes and hobby interests I upload to a website maintained for that purpose and carried under a proxy for whois purposes. Not much use to anyone else if they did crack the proxy holder. Our investments and all other personally identifiable, sensitive financial information are on a stand-alone PC with no Internet connection and the backup CD goes in the safe.

I stopped using online banking a few years ago and technically regressed to picking up the telephone for banking requirements as our bank digitally records all incoming calls and assigns personal bankers for account holders.  computers have gotten easier, and hardware cheaper. You can pick up a dedicated firewall on Ebay for $100-$200 and not have to worry much. 
 
 the problem with switching to Apple is that their percieved invulnerability does not come from the fact that they are all that secure, but from the fact that businesses rarely use them and there are not many out there, so most hackers see learning the ins and outs as a waste of time. My sister has an apple, and my IT guy at the office would routinely take control of her system to fix problems. If you end up with a hacker who HAS bothered to take the time to learn a bit abotu the system, your computer is theirs. 
 
 Linux is without a doubt the most secure system available, and easy enough to set up at home without needing an IT pro.
 
 Personally, I run a honeypot in fornt of my firewalled system (el cheapo computer from Ebay...old netier SL series terminals work well and don't take up much room). The way it is set up, I have a machine running windows 2K connected to my internet connection, then to my server. That front machine is running (I think) a zone alarm firewall. The server behind it is running linux with an IPchains firewall. Since the linux firewall is highly configurable, it can be set to refuse any connection (or answer any pings) from the access box that it has not initiated. Hacker hits the access box, breaks through the zone alarm firewall, and thinks they are in. Scanning other ports, etc... does them no good, since the server is impervious to such things. From the outside, the access computer looks like a standalone machine. They never get any further.

The OS is VERY stable, when using approved programs. Unfortunatly the stability of an OS is not based on how it handles well written and properly constructed programs, but on how it handles poorly constructed apps that tend to misbehave. In this regard, Microsoft is light years ahead of Mac (yes, it hurts to say that). It is relatively difficult to write a program that will crash a windows system utterly and completely. You actually have to try in order to do it. A good friend who owns a compnay that develops some fairly well known mac software keeps a whole room of spare machines and a tech who does nothing but re-install operating systems because during the course of testing misbehaving apps routinely scrag systems. 
 
 In short, I think that ont he desk of a computer geek is where you are least likely to find a mac/apple. They (apple) tend to market their machines as an alternative to people who want something a little different and little prettier (big selling point). At one time, they were pretty much the undisputed champs when it came to desktop publishing and even video editing.
